Fig 2 Fig. 3 (a) Catalyst preparation process, (b) (c) SEM, (d) TEM, (e) HR-TEM, (j) SEM-EDS of Ni-15CoOx/Hβ-u catalyst and (f) (g) SEM, (h) TEM, (i) HR-TEM of Ni-15CoOx/Hβ catalyst. Reaction conditions: 60 mg substrate, 180 °C, 1.0 MPa H2, 20 mL n-hexane. The high oxygen content and low calorific value of bio-oil make it unsuitable for direct production of high energy density fuels. To address this issue, the C-O-C, C-O-H, and C-C bonds in the oxygenated compounds of bio-oil can be modified through hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) reaction. In this study, we synthesized a series of efficient Ni-CoOx/Hβ-u catalysts by impregnating Hβ molecular sieve modified with urea under mild conditions. The catalytic HDO performance of these catalysts was evaluated using guaiacol and dealkalized lignin oil as substrates. The results indicate that the Ni-15CoOx/Hβ-u catalyst demonstrated superior activity. The suitable specific surface area and pore volume of the Ni-15CoOx/Hβ-u catalysts, as well as uniformly dispersed metal particles on their surface, increased the number of active sites available for HDO. Additionally, the presence of defective sites on the CoOx surface and acidic sites on the catalyst facilitate the breaking of intermediate C-O bonds (deoxygenation) and dehydration reactions. Utilizing the Ni-15CoOx/Hβ-u catalysts, guaiacol was completely converted to cyclohexane with 100% selectivity (at 180 °C, 1.0 MPa H2, 40 min). Furthermore, the phenolic compounds in bio-oil could also be transformed into cycloalkanes via the HDO process. These findings suggest that the Ni-15CoOx/Hβ-u catalyst has the potential to effectively hydrodeoxygenate bio-oil under mild reaction conditions. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Non-noble metal catalyst Guaiacol Hydrodeoxygenation Bio-oil Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The over dependence on fossil energy has intensified the global energy crisis and caused substantial environmental problems [1]. In light to the growing demand for carbon-neutral progress, the exploration of renewable energy as a substitute for fossil resources has garnered considerable interest from researchers [2–4]. Biomass constitutes a distinctive renewable energy resource in nature due to its renewable aromatic compound content and is regarded as a promising alternative to fossil-derived materials. Lignocellulose, comprising lignin, cellulose, and hemicellulose, is the primary constituent of biomass [5]. Lignin, one of the key lignocellulosic components, is an amorphous polymer composed of phenylpropane units linked by C-C and ether bonds, abundant in aromatic rings and oxygen-containing functional groups. Selective cleavage of the connection bonds between lignin structural units can facilitate the value-added utilization of lignin for the production of various chemicals [6]. Typically, the utilization of lignin involves converting the solid lignin into pyrolysis oil through rapid pyrolysis [7]. The bio-oil produced by rapid pyrolysis has a high oxygen content, low calorific value, high viscosity and poor chemical stability, which constrain its widespread application [8,9]. Therefore, a subsequent catalytic hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) process is essential to enhance the H/C and C/O ratios of bio-oil, thereby improving its quality and versatility. Bio-oils are rich functional groups, including methoxy (R-O-CH3), phenolic hydroxyl (R-O-H), aliphatic hydroxyl (R-O-H), benzyl alcohol (R-CH2-O-H), non-cyclic phenyl ether (R-O-R). The complex structure of bio-oils increases the challenge of developing efficient catalysts and understanding the related reaction mechanisms [10]. To elucidate the HDO reaction mechanism, researchers frequently employ lignin oil-derived compounds such as guaiacol, phenol, o-toluene, p-toluene, eugenol and other compounds containing C-O bonds [11–13]. Numerous catalysts have been investigated for the HDO of bio-oil, including noble metals (Pt, Pt, Ru), non-noble metals (Ni, Co, Cu), metal sulfides and transition metal nitrides [14–17]. Marlowe et al [18] investigated the structural organization of WOx/Pt catalyst and their effect on HDO reaction using a combination of theoretical and experimental methods. DFT calculations revealed the preferential adsorption sites of WOx on Pt surfaces, while machine learning algorithms identified the key features that stabilize WOx. Yan et al [19] synthesized CuCoO and CuCoCeOx catalysts for guaiacol HDO, revealing the mechanisms that Cu-induced hydrogen spillover leads to the deactivation of CuCo. Noble metal catalysts demonstrate high activity. However, their high cost constrains their application in industrial settings [20]. Metal sulfides and metal nitrides also exhibit good HDO performance, but the generation of water during the HDO process can readily deactivate these catalysts [21]. In contrast, transition metal catalysts are more affordable, and their modification can yield performance comparable to that of noble metals, garnering significant interest for the HDO reaction [22,23]. Hence, the synthesis of highly active non-noble metal catalysts for HDO is pivotal in advancing the value-added applications of bio-oil. Up to now, it has been reported that catalysts containing acidic sites often possess superior CarOCH3– dissociation capabilities. Zhou et al [24] modulated the acidity of the catalyst by incorporating metal Co, resulting in the NiCo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst exhibiting higher activity than the Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst under equivalent conditions, with cyclohexanol as the predominant product. This enhancement is attributed to the increased acidity, reducibility, and metal particle dispersion caused by the introduction of Co, which in turn enhances the catalytic activity. Hong et al [25] synthesized various zeolite catalysts, including HY, Hβ, and HZSM-5, for the conversion of phenol. They found that the product selectivity is closely related to the shape and acidity of the zeolite. Additionally, oxyphilic metals such as W, Fe, Co, and Mo exhibit a high affinity for oxygen atoms. Wu et al [26] developed a Co-MoS2-x catalyst via a solvothermal method, achieving the HDO of 4-methylphenol at 120 °C and demonstrating robust performance in converting various lignin monomers and even bio-oil into aromatic hydrocarbons. Cheng et al [27] prepared non-sulfided Fe-Co/SiO2 catalyst for bio-oil HDO. The moderate acidic Fe-Co/SiO2 catalyst, featuring oxyphilic Fe and Co metals, displayed exceptional HDO activity, with the hydrocarbon content reaching up to 22.44%. Hu et al [28] prepared a series of Mo/NiFe71-V single-atom catalysts (SACs) and investigated their performance in the HDO of lignin and its phenolic derivatives. They found that the catalytic performance was influenced by the charge transfer-induced Mo-Ni metal-metal interaction. Nonetheless, a significant challenge in HDO reactions is the rational control of acidic and metal active sites on catalysts to direct product selectivity. Therefore, a comprehensive understanding of catalyst properties and the intricate mechanisms of HDO reaction pathways is essential for the effective upgrading and utilization of bio-oil. In our previous study [29], we found that Ni0.5Co1.5Al catalysts can effectively cleave C-O bonds in various lignin via catalytic transfer hydrogenolysis (CTH) to produce phenolic compounds. Given the high oxygen content of these phenolic compounds, it is crucial to explore HDO catalysts for the upgrading and subsequent utilization of lignin oil. In this work, a series of Ni-CoOx/Hβ-u catalysts were prepared for the HDO of lignin-derived phenolic compounds and lignin oil under mild conditions. Combining the characterization results of XRD, SEM, TEM, XPS, NH3-TPD, etc., the structure-performance relationship of the catalyst and its impact on the HDO reaction of guaiacol and bio-oil were deeply discussed. The results show that the Ni-15CoOx/Hβ-u catalyst exhibits a suitable specific surface area and pore volume, which provides more active sites for HDO reaction. The variable valence and oxygen affinity of Co metal in the catalyst provide more oxygen vacancies and deoxygenation binding sites, leading to high selectivity for HDO of phenolic compounds under mild conditions. Furthermore, based on the reaction products obtained from the HDO of guaiacol and bio-oil, a reaction pathway for the selective catalytic HDO of phenolic compounds using the Ni-15CoOx/Hβ-u catalyst was proposed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials All chemicals in this work are analytical purity and used without any purification. Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (99%,), guaiacol (99%), phenol (99%), p-cresol (98%), m-cresol (98%), 4-Methylanisole (98%), 2-Methoxy-4-propylphenol (98%) 2,6-Dimethoxy-4-methylphenol (98%) and 2,6-Dimethoxy-4-propylphenol (98%) were purchased from Aladdin Reagents (Shanghai, China) Co. Co(NO3)2·6H2O (99%) and urea were obtained from Maclean's Reagents (Shanghai, China) Co. Furthermore, methanol and n-hexane were purchased from Xilong Chemical. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Hβ zeolite (Si/Al = 25 was obtained from Nankai Catalysts Co., Ltd (Tianjin, China). All zeolites were calcined in a muffle furnace at 550 °C (heating rate 5 °C/min) for 5 h before use. The Ni-CoOx/Hβ catalysts were prepared by simple impregnation-calcination-reduction method. Typically, 0.4 mmol of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, 0.4 mmol of Co(NO3)2·6H2O and 0.08 mmol of urea were dissolved in 20 mL of methanol, and then 0.25 g of Hβ was added. The obtained suspension was heated to 60 °C and stirred at 200 r/min for 12 h, then stirred at room temperature for 12 h. The methanol in the mixture was removed at 37 °C under heating and vacuum at 200 hPa. The precipitate was dried in a vacuum oven at 80 °C for 2 h. Then it was ground into powder form and calcined in a muffle furnace at 550 °C for 3 h with a heating rate of 2 °C/min. Finally, the catalyst was reduced in a tube furnace at a heating rate of 2 °C/min in flowing H2 at 500 °C for 2 h. The catalyst obtained was noted as Ni-10CoOx/Hβ-u. Changing the amount of Co(NO3)2·6H2O added enabled the preparation of CoOx/Hβ-u, Ni-5CoOx/Hβ-u, Ni-15CoOx/Hβ-u and Ni-20CoOx/Hβ-u catalysts. 2.3 Catalyst characterizations X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns of catalysts were measured on the German Bruker D8 ADVANCE X-ray using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.5142 nm). The XRD patterns were obtained by scanning with 0.02° increments in the diffraction angle range of 4–80°. The N2 adsorption at 77 K was determined on a Quantachrome Autosorb-iQ device, and the pore structure of samples and the specific surface area were determined with the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method and the Brunauer-Emmettt-Teller (BET) method. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were carried out using the Thermo Scientific ESCALAB 250Xi with Al Kα X-rays (1486.7 eV), the C1s from the carbon contaminated (Eb=284.8 eV) site were used as internal standard. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) measurement was carried out with the Bruker EMXplus-6/1 spectrometer (Germany). Hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and ammonia temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) analyses were performed on a Chembet Pulsert TPR type chemical instrument with thermal conductivity detector. In the typical procedure, 50 mg catalyst sample was prepared in argon at 200 °C for 1 h, then cooled to 50 °C and saturated with 10 % H2/Ar. Following this, the sample was purged with helium at a flow rate of 30 mL/min to remove excess physically adsorbed hydrogen. For the NH3-TPD test, the catalyst was pretreated with Ar at 250 °C for 2 h and then cooled to 100 °C. After saturation of NH3 adsorption, the catalyst was purified with Ar for 1 h to remove the physically adsorbed NH3. Eventually, the catalyst was heated from 100 to 800 °C. DG/DTG curves were obtained using a Netzsch thermal analyzer (Germany) in the temperature range of 30–600 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Agilent 7850 inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) was used to measure metal loading. The morphology of catalyst was obtained using a scanning electron microscopy (ZEISS Sigma 300). Energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) elemental mapping was used to analysis the distribution of metal species. The metal particle size distribution of different ratios was employed by FEI Tecnai G2 F20 transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-resolution transmission electron microscopic (HR-TEM). For the catalysts particle size distribution were calculated as follows: first about 200 nanoparticles were counted and then the average particle size was calculated using the formula ( d n = ∑ n i d i / n i , where n i mean the number of particles, d i mean the particle diameter). 2.4 Catalyst test and product analysis The HDO experiments of lignin-derived monomer model compounds and bio-oil were carried out in a 100 mL stainless steel autoclave reactor. In a typical experiment, substrate (60 mg), catalyst (20 mg) and n-hexane (20 mL) were added to the autoclave. After removing air three times with high purity nitrogen, the reactor was added with 1.0 MPa H2 and then heated to the desired temperature for the time required at a stirring rate of 300 r/min. The identification of the products was performed on an Agilent 7890A-5975C GC-MS instrument equipped with an HP-5 capillary column (60 m × 250 μm × 0.25 μm). The inlet temperature was 60 °C, the carrier gas was high purity helium, and the shunt ratio was set to 50:1. The conversion and yield of the product were calculated according to the following equation: (1) Conversion = ( 1 − m o l e o f s u b s t r a t e i n t h e l i q u i d p h a s e i n i t i a l m o l e o f s u b s t r a t e ) × 100 % (2) Yield = m o l e o f e a c h p r o d u c t t o t a l m o l e o f s u b s t r a t e 2.5 simulated calculation Quantum chemical calculations were conducted utilizing the Gaussian 09 software package [30]. The level of geometrical optimization was set to B3LYP/6–31G(d,p), and the absence of imaginary frequencies confirmed that the optimized structure represented the minimum structure. The distribution of the electrostatic potential between C-O bonds on the van der Waals surface in the model compounds was analyzed using Multiwfn. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The physical and chemical properties of the catalysts were analyzed using various characterization methods. Fig. 1 exhibits the X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the prepared catalysts. The characteristic absorption peaks of Hβ appeared at 7.93°, 22.49°, 25.34°, 27.08° and 29.66° [31–33]. The XRD spectra of the urea-modified catalysts are essentially same as those of unmodified catalysts, indicating that the urea-modified of molecular sieves method is a relatively mild treatment. The peaks at 36.49°, 42.38° and 61.49° correspond to the (111), (200) and (220) crystal planes of CoO (PDF#43–1004), and the peaks at 37.28°, 43.27° and 62.87° attribute to the (111), (200) and (220) crystal planes of NiO (PDF#47–1049), respectively [34,35]. Due to the similar positions of the diffraction peaks of CoO and NiO, the main diffraction peaks in the Ni-CoOx/Hβ-u and Ni-CoOx/Hβ catalysts are attributed to NiO, CoO or their complexes [36]. The peaks at 44.50° and 51.84° belong to the metal Ni (111) and (200) (PDF#04–0850) [37]. The results reveal that the catalyst contains metallic Ni, while Co is present in the form of oxides. Additionally, due to their similar lattice parameters, electronegativity, crystal structures and atomic radii, Ni and Co can combine and form interactions during the calcination process. The N2 adsorption isotherms and corresponding pore size distributions of the catalysts are depicted in Fig. 2 . According to the IUPAC classification, both the Ni-15CoOx/Hβ-u and Ni-15CoOx/Hβ catalysts display type IV isotherms accompanied by type-H2 hysteresis loops, which signify a predominant mesoporous structure (Fig. 2a). As shown in Table S1, the Ni-15CoOx/Hβ-u catalyst possesses a BET surface area of 480.59 m2/g and a pore volume of 373.93 cm3/g. The porous structure of the catalyst is beneficial for the dispersion of the metal active sites on the carrier surface [38,39]. It was observed that the specific surface area of the Ni-15CoOx/Hβ catalyst is slightly smaller than that of Ni-15CoOx/Hβ-u, and the total pore volume follows the same trend. This reduction is primarily attributed to the release of gases from urea decomposition during the calcination process. The evacuation of these gases between the particles counteracts catalytic sintering, thereby influencing the specific surface area and pore volume of the catalyst. The SEM and TEM images of Ni-CoOx/Hβ-u and Ni-CoOx/Hβ catalysts are exhibited in Fig. 3 . It can be clearly seen that the surface morphology of Ni-CoOx/Hβ-u catalyst is rough with regularly stacked grains (Fig 3b, 3c), and the Ni, Co, Al, Si and O elements are uniformly dispersed on the carrier (Fig. 3j). Whereas there is a phenomenon of particle agglomeration on the surface of Ni-CoOx/Hβ catalyst, indicating that the metal and urea modification methods have retained the intact pore shape structure of the Hβ. The TEM image of Ni-CoOx/Hβ-u and Ni-CoOx/Hβ catalysts are shown in Fig. 3d and Fig. 3h, where the particle size of the Ni-CoOx/Hβ-u catalyst is smaller at 3.43 nm. In addition, The lattice fringes of NiO(200) and Ni(111) can be observed in the HR-TEM images of the catalysts, which implies the presence of metallic Ni on the catalysts. The ICP-MS results show that the content of metal Co in the catalysts increases with the increase in the amount of Co(NO3)2·6H2O added, while the content of metal Ni shows a gradually decreasing tendency. This probably because the increased addition of Co(NO3)2·6H2O affects the impregnation of metal Ni (Table S2). The NH3-TPD profiles of Ni-CoOx/Hβ-u and Ni-CoOx/Hβ catalysts are shown in Fig. 4 . The peaks below 250°C are indicative of weakly acidic sites, those within the range of 250–420 °C represent medium-strong acidic sites, and those between 420 °C and 550 °C correspond to strongly acidic sites [40]. As shown in Table S3, the Ni-15CoOx/Hβ-u catalyst exhibits a slight reduction in the intensity of medium acid sites and an increase in strong acid sites. It is probably attributed to the influence of the alkaline environment on the crystallization process and the skeletal structure of the molecular sieves after the introduction of urea, resulting in easier access of the aluminum atoms to the molecular sieve skeleton and the formation of more acidic sites. The H2-TPR characterization results for the catalyst are presented in Fig. S1. Two primary reduction peaks corresponding to metallic Ni were identified on the Ni/Hβ-u catalyst. The reduction peak at a lower temperature of 280°C is associated with the reduction of free NiO, while the peak at a higher temperature of 435°C corresponds to the reduction of NiO species that exhibit weak interaction with the carrier material [41]. The strong interaction induced by electron transfer between NiO and CoOx shifts the reduction temperature of NiO on the Ni-15CoOx/Hβ-u catalyst to a higher temperature region, requiring a higher reduction temperature. The peak observed around 380 °C likely corresponds to the reduction of Co2O3 to CoO, while the peak at high temperature (>500 °C) can attributed to the reduction of Co2+ ions [42,43]. Unlike monometallic systems, the addition of CoOx modifies alters the metal-support interaction, resulting in a shift in the reduction peak temperature [44]. Specifically, the reduction peak for the Ni-CoOx/Hβ-u catalyst shifts to a higher temperature, signifying a stronger interaction between the active metal and the support [45]. This enhanced interaction contributes positively to the stability of the catalyst. XPS spectroscopy was further performed to analyze the catalyst surface chemical composition. In Fig. 5 a, the most intense doublet (855 eV and 873 eV) can be ascribed to Ni2+ in NiO, and the second doublet (861 eV and 879 eV) may be attributed to Ni2+ in Ni (OH)2 [46]. The presence of NiO and Ni(OH)2 is due to the easy oxidation of the reduced Ni atom surface when exposed to air in the presence of water, resulting in the formation of Ni oxides and hydroxides. Upon exposure to air, the surface of the reduced Ni atoms readily undergoes oxidation, resulting in the formation of Ni oxides and hydroxides. Consequently, the presence of NiO and Ni(OH)₂ was observed. In Fig. 5b, the Co2p spectrum of the catalyst shows two spin-orbit peaks corresponding to Co 2p1/2 and Co 2p3/2. The peaks at 780 eV and 793 eV correspond to Co2+, and the peaks at 782 eV and 803 eV belong to Co3+ [47]. No peaks of single linear state of nickel were detected in Ni/Hβ-u and CoOx/Hβ-u catalysts, which may be attributed to the formation of surface nickel oxide species (NiO) after exposure to air. Compared to the Ni/Hβ-u and CoOx/Hβ-u catalysts, the electronic binding energy of Ni2p shifted to higher potentials while the binding energy of Co2p showed a decreasing trend in the Ni-CoOx/Hβ-u catalysts, implying the existence of electronic interactions between Ni and Co. As is known, Co exhibits less electronegativity and Ni has a stronger ability to attract electrons than Co [48]. Hence, the electron transfer from Co to Ni leading to the electron-rich Ni and electron-deficient Co atoms. Su et al [49] reported that the electron transfer is conducive to enhancing the synergistic interaction of the active components in the catalyst, thus facilitating the hydrogenolysis process (Ni-Co-MOF). Additionally, the ratio of Co2+/Co3+ in the Ni-CoOx/Hβ-u catalyst was higher than that in the CoOx/Hβ-u, indicating that the introduction of Ni affects the reduction of Co, which is beneficial for optimizing the ratio of Co2 +/Co3 + and improve the catalytic performance of the catalysts (Table S4). Furthermore, the O1s spectral peak distributions and corresponding contents of the catalyst are shown in Fig. S2 and Table S5. The O1s spectrum exhibits three distinct peaks at 530.9, 532.5, and 533.3 eV, which are attributed to lattice oxygen (OL), oxygen vacancies (OV), and physically bound water (OH), respectively [50–52]. The Ni-CoOx/Hβ-u catalyst exhibited the highest oxygen vacancy content, which could be due to the cobalt doping disrupting the Si-O structure, resulting in more oxygen vacancies (OV). Furthermore, the Ni-CoOx/Hβ-u catalyst was characterized by electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) to detect unpaired electronic structure and the abundance of defective site. The peak at g=2.003 in Fig. S3 is assigned to oxygen defect [53,54], providing strong evidence that the multiple oxidation states of metallic cobalt generate defective CoOx sites, which is consistent with the XPS results.. 3.2 HDO of guaiacol The phenolic compound guaiacol, characterized by its hydroxyl and methoxy groups, is a prevalent component in bio-oil and is routinely used as a model substrate to evaluate the activity of HDO catalysts. Table 1 demonstrates the limited effectiveness of the unmodified Hβ-u support in facilitating guaiacol conversion under controlled experimental conditions. However, the introduction of Ni onto the Hβ-u support (Ni/Hβ-u catalyst) improved guaiacol conversion to 23.09%. The addition of CoOx to the Hβ-u support (CoOx/Hβ-u) further enhanced guaiacol conversion by 49.09%. Utilizing the Ni-15CoOx/Hβ catalyst for guaiacol conversion resulted in a total conversion of 92.88%, yielding cyclohexane (CH), cyclohexanol (CHOH), trans-1-methyl-1,2-cyclohexanediol (t-MCHD), and 1,2-cyclohexanediol (CHD) with product yields of 33.17%, 5.46%, 23.56%, and 30.69%, respectively. In contrast, when the Ni-15CoOx/Hβ-u catalyst was employed, a selectivity of 100% for cyclohexane was achieved. As is known, CoOx species served as the acidic sites facilitated the breaking of the C-O bond during the reaction. Since the content of CoOx species in catalysts increased with the increase in metal Co content [19]. Consequently, the conversion of guaiacol was significantly increased. The comparative evaluation of these catalysts revealed that the Ni-15CoOx/Hβ-u catalyst displayed superior hydrodeoxygenation performance, warranting its selection for further investigation. These findings indicate that the metal-modified molecular sieve can serve as an effective reaction center for the hydrodeoxygenation of guaiacol, significantly enhancing both conversion and product selectivity. Fig. 6 a illustrates the effect of hydrogen pressure on the catalytic conversion of guaiacol. At a hydrogen pressure of 0.5 MPa, the conversion of guaiacol is 67.64%, yielding cyclohexane as the sole product. When the hydrogen pressure is increasing from 0.5 MPa to 1 MPa, both the conversion of guaiacol and the yield of cyclohexanol reach 100%, indicating that higher hydrogen pressure enhances the hydrodeoxygenation of guaiacol to cyclohexane. However, raising the hydrogen pressure further to 2.0 MPa does not lead to a notable change in either the conversion of guaiacol or the yield of cyclohexane. Consequently, a hydrogen pressure of 1.0 MPa is determined as the optimal condition for this reaction in the catalytic system. In addition to the hydrogen pressure, the reaction temperature and duration also significantly affect the HDO of guaiacol. Therefore, the optimized Ni-15CoOx/Hβ-u catalyst was employed for the HDO of guaiacol at different temperatures (160–200 °C) and for various durations (10–40 min). As depicted in Fig. 6, at a relatively low temperature of 160 °C, guaiacol conversion was minimal, with a high abundance of intermediates. At reaction temperatures of 180 °C and 200 °C, guaiacol was completely converted to cyclohexane after 40 min with 100% selectivity. At 180 °C, the conversion of guaiacol increased gradually, with only minor intermediate products detected during the initial 30 min of the reaction. However, when the reaction temperature was raised to 200 °C, the intermediate products were only observed during the first 10 min and guaiacol was fully transformed to cyclohexane after 30 min with 100% selectivity. Clearly, an increase in reaction temperature promotes the conversion of intermediates, thereby improving product selectivity. As illustrated in Fig. 7 a, an increase in catalyst dosage is associated with a higher conversion of guaiacol. The relationship between reaction rate and varying catalyst dosages is depicted in Fig. 7b. To circumvent potential issues related to mass transfer limitations and competitive adsorption of products, the reaction rate is calculated based on the conversion rate of guaiacol during the initial 40 min. This calculation is predicated on the assumption that the number of active sites is directly proportional to the amount of catalyst added into the reactor. As shown in Fig. 7, the R2 value for the fitted line is 0.981, suggesting a linear relationship between the reaction rate of guaiacol and the amount of catalyst used. Therefore, the HDO reaction of guaiacol follows first-order kinetics (θ = 1). Jiang et al [55] reported that the adsorption and activation of H2 on metal sites ion results in the formation of oppositely charged hydrogen ions (H+ and H-). Thes ions can promote the hydrogenation of aromatic rings and the cleavage of C-O bonds. Liu et al [56] found that atoms with negative charges and smaller Mulliken charge values exhibit a higher affinity for superior H+ adsorption capabilities, whereas atoms with positive charges and larger Mulliken charge values tent to bind H-. Luo et al [57] discovered that the catalysts with acidic sites, H+ preferentially bind to the *O sites in aryl ether compounds, thus promoting the cleavage of C-O bonds. As demonstrated in Table S6, the Mulliken charge values for oxygen atoms 11 and 13 in guaiacol are -0.401 and -0.432, respectively, suggesting a tendency for H+ to absorb at these sites. The induction of the phenolic hydroxyl group results in a Mulliken charge value of 0.167 for carbon 4 and -0.133 for carbon 3, indicating that the former is more likely to bind H- and the latter to bind H+. This suggest that the oxygen atom of the guaiacol hydroxyl group is likely to be adsorbed onto the defective CoOx site. The hydrogen ion (H+) released from the metal Ni active site and the catalyst's acidic site possesses a positive charge. Consequently, the C-O bonds at the active site on the catalyst surface are broken, leading to the removal of the oxygen atom and completing the deoxygenation reaction via hydrogenation. 3.3 HDO of other lignin model compounds To evaluate the universality of the Ni-15CoOx/Hβ-u catalyst for bio-oil HDO, a series of HDO experiments were conducted on various phenolic compounds commonly present in bio-oil under uniform reaction conditions. As presented in Table 2 , phenol is readily converted to cyclohexane, and the presence of different substituents on the benzene ring significantly affects the substrate HDO process. The results demonstrate that o-cresol, m-cresol, and p-cresol can be completely hydrodeoxygenated to form cyclohexane under the established reaction conditions. When 2,6-methylphenol was used as the reaction substrate, the Ni-15CoOx/Hβ-u also facilitated its complete conversion to cyclohexane, demonstrating the catalyst's favorable hydrodeoxygenation activity. Moreover, p-methoxybenzene can be completely converted to toluene, 2-methoxy-3-propyl-phenol and 2,6-dimethoxy-3-propyl-phenol can be fully converted to n-propyl cyclohexane. Fig. 8 (d)-(f) illustrate the electrostatic potential energy (ESP) distribution for o-cresol, guaiacol and 4-propyl-2-methoxyphenol. Region where ESPs exhibit a more negative value indicates an electron concentration. Owing to the pronounced electronegativity, electrons accumulate near the O atoms of o-cresol, guaiacol and 4-propyl-2-methoxyphenol. The p-π conjugation effect extends this high-density electron cloud to the aromatic rings (ARs) directly attached to the O atoms, which is particularly noticeable in o-cresol. Furthermore, the methyl group is an electron-releasing group that can increase the electron density on the benzene ring through an induced effect, and methoxy group is a strong electron-donating group that significantly increases the electron density on the benzene ring through both a conjugation effect and an induced effect. The propyl group, a larger alkyl substituent, primarily affects the reaction through steric effects and has a less pronounced effect on the electron density compared to methyl and methoxy. For o-cresol, the methyl group may facilitate the protonation of oxygen atoms due to induced effects, thus favoring the hydrodeoxygenation reaction. However, in guaiacol, the electron-donating and steric effects of methoxy group could hinder the protonation and departure of oxygen atoms, negatively affecting the hydrodeoxygenation process. The propyl group in 4-propyl-2-methoxyphenol might obstruct the catalyst's access to the oxygen atom, reducing its reactivity. Nonetheless, its induced effect might marginally promote the departure of oxygen atoms. Consequently, even at elevated reaction temperatures, the propyl group in 4-propyl-2-methoxyphenol remains intact. These findings suggest that the Ni-15CoOx/Hβ-u catalyst selectively promotes the removal of hydroxyl and methoxy groups from complex substrates while effectively preserving other functional groups in the original model compounds. 3.4 HDO of bio-oil Although lignin model compounds are commonly used to assess the HDO performance of the Ni-15CoOx/Hβ-u catalyst, real bio-oil is typically a complex mixture of various compounds. Therefore, the catalytic efficacy of the Ni-15CoOx/Hβ-u catalyst in bio-oil requires further verification. To investigate the catalytic activity of the Ni-15CoOx/Hβ-u catalyst in a more realistic reaction system, simulated bio-oil was prepared by blending five compounds commonly present in bio-oil: guaiacol, 4-methylanisole (4-MeAN), m-cresol (M-Cres), 2,6-dimethoxy-4-methylphenol (2,6-DiMeO-4-MePh), and 2-methoxy-4-propylphenol (2-MeO-4-PrPh) in defined ratios. Following the reaction of the simulated bio-oil, gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC–MS) analysis revealed the formation of only cyclohexane (CH), methylcyclohexane (MCH), and n-propylcyclohexane (n-PCH). This indicated that the Ni-15CoOx/Hβ-u catalyst effectively catalyzed the HDO of the simulated bio-oil, resulting in the production of cycloalkanes with high conversion efficiency of the complex mixture into the desired products. Fig. S6 and Table S7 indicate that the relative percentage content of phenolic compounds in bio-oil is approximately 81.49%. However, subsequent to the HDO processes, the concentration of these phenolic compounds decreases, with only six primary types remaining detectable. The relative percentage content of guaiacol, which initially constituted 44.25% of the bio-oil, is decreased to just 6.45%. Conversely, the highest content observed among the products is approximately 14.02% for methylcyclohexane. The alkylated hydrocarbons together make up 41.2% of the product mixture, indicating that the majority of the hydroxyl and methoxy groups present in the phenolic compounds have been removed through the HDO process. Nevertheless, some phenolic compounds can still be detected in the bio-oil after the HDO reaction. The phenomenon may be attributed to the diversity and complexity of compounds within bio-oil, wherein phenolic hydroxyl groups readily form hydrogen bonds with other oxygen-containing functional groups and aromatic rings. This suggests that the HDO process may require further optimization to achieve complete conversion of phenolic compounds in bio-oil. 3.5 Catalyst recyclability The cycling performance of the Ni-15CoOx/Hβ-u catalyst in the guaiacol HDO reaction was examined under the optimal reaction conditions. As illustrated in Fig. S7, the Ni-15CoOx/Hβ-u catalyst exhibits magnetic characteristics, which facilitate its separation and recycling using a magnetic field. The conversion rate of guaiacol began to decrease after the second cycle, dropping to 87.6% by the fifth cycle. Notably, despite the conversion of guaiacol decreased, the selectivity of cyclohexane remained at 100%, indicating that the activity of the catalyst decreased without changing the selectivity of the products. To ascertain the reasons of catalyst deactivation, thermogravimetric analysis (TG) was performed on both the fresh catalyst and the catalyst after it had been subjected to five cycles (Fig. 9 ). Compared to the uncalcined precipitate (Fig. S4) and fresh catalyst, two peaks appeared on the DTG curve of the catalyst after five cycles, corresponding to the weight loss observed on the TG curve. The peak below 200 °C is associated to the evaporation of water trapped with the catalyst, along with the removal of adsorbed impurities from the surface and pores of the catalyst. This is reflected by a slight decrease on the TG curve, and the water evaporation peak evident on the DTG curve. Above 200 °C, the catalyst started to lose weight slowly, with the rate of weight loss increasing as the temperature rose, signifying the oxidation of carbon deposits on the catalyst [58–60]. In the temperature range of 400–500 °C, decomposition and depolymerization reactions occurred. The fresh catalyst exhibited weight loss only at temperatures below 200 °C and did not show significant weight loss in the high-temperature range. This suggests that the deactivation of the catalyst after the cycling process was primarily due to the carbon deposition on the catalyst surface. 4 Conclusions In summary, Hβ zeolite was modified using a urea treatment, and the resulting material was used to synthesize the Ni-15CoOx/Hβ-u catalyst via a simple impregnation method for the HDO of phenolic compounds. Using guaiacol as a model compound, the Ni-15CoOx/Hβ-u catalyst demonstrated remarkable selectivity for HDO activity. Under a hydrogen atmosphere of 1.0 MPa, guaiacol was fully converted to cyclohexane after a 40 min reaction at 180 °C, with n-hexane serving as the solvent, achieving a 100% selectivity for cyclohexane. The main reaction pathway for guaiacol conversion involved the direct cleavage of the Car-OH and Car-OCH3 bonds, with cyclohexane being the main product of the HDO reaction. Moreover, the Ni-15CoOx/Hβ-u catalyst also exhibited high HDO activity towards a variety of lignin-derived phenolic compounds and bio-oil. Appendix A. coredata.dc:description: The high oxygen content and low calorific value of bio-oil make it unsuitable for direct production of high energy density fuels. To address this issue, the C-O-C, C-O-H, and C-C bonds in the oxygenated compounds of bio-oil can be modified through hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) reaction. In this study, we synthesized a series of efficient Ni-CoOx/Hβ-u catalysts by impregnating Hβ molecular sieve modified with urea under mild conditions. The catalytic HDO performance of these catalysts was evaluated using guaiacol and dealkalized lignin oil as substrates. The results indicate that the Ni-15CoOx/Hβ-u catalyst demonstrated superior activity. The suitable specific surface area and pore volume of the Ni-15CoOx/Hβ-u catalysts, as well as uniformly dispersed metal particles on their surface, increased the number of active sites available for HDO. Additionally, the presence of defective sites on the CoOx surface and acidic sites on the catalyst facilitate the breaking of intermediate C-O bonds (deoxygenation) and dehydration reactions. Utilizing the Ni-15CoOx/Hβ-u catalysts, guaiacol was completely converted to cyclohexane with 100% selectivity (at 180 °C, 1.0 MPa H2, 40 min). Furthermore, the phenolic compounds in bio-oil could also be transformed into cycloalkanes via the HDO process. These findings suggest that the Ni-15CoOx/Hβ-u catalyst has the potential to effectively hydrodeoxygenate bio-oil under mild reaction conditions.
